explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 85degC (c.c.) (NFPA (13th, 2002)) which is classified into Category 4.

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 482degC (ICSC, 2004)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 698mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 670mg/kg, 940mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 97-21 (1998)) and 900mg/kg (CICAD No.7 (1998)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 3,235mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 3,235mg/kg (CICAD No.7 (1998)) and 3,250mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 97-21 (1998)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 value of 3.86mg/L (4 hours), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 862ppm (4 hours) (RTECS (2006)) was lower than 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (2,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.2kPa (20degC) (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004)): "Slightly irritating to the skin" (though it is unclear whether the results are those of 4-hour application).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "eye irritation" of unknown degree (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004)). The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin sensitizer: Classification not possible
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: No data available

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests and chromosome aberration tests), described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004), IARC 77 (2000) and NTP DB (Access on Feb., 2006).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005), Group 2A by IARC (2000) and Category 2A by the Japan Society for Occupational Health.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, blood system, kidneys, bladder)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "headache, fatigue, dizziness or nausea" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004)), "severe dyspnea, perspiration, cyanosis and hematuria" (CERI Hazard Data 97-21 (1998)), "causes irritation of the kidney and bladder, inducing hematuria" (MOE Risk Assessment vol.3 (2004)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "methemoglobinemia (6-19%)" (DFGOT vol.3 1992), and the evidence from animal studies including "congestion of the spleen, increased extramedullary hematopoiesis, hemosiderin deposition and increased bone marrow cells" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.202 (2004)), "methemoglobinemia, erythropenia and reticulocytosis" (CERI Hazard Data 97-21 (1998)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours EC50=8mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI Hazard Data, 1997).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 2 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (log Kow=1.32(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 5%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 2.
